instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN: What is PM_PWRBTN? PM_PWRBTN refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Resistor <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> keeps blowing up..  History: Water damage

Checked all the caps and resistor around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.. all ok..

[ATTACH type="full" alt="Skärmbild (81).png"]59463[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground at <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR>/98; red probe connected to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> = 0.107
<CAPACITOR>C7098</CAPACITOR> = 0.303

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> = 0.107"
Really bad...

Remove <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR>-92 one by one and check again.
If still low, replace <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>; most likely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thanks, Master it worked.
I removed <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> and without the cap it shows now = 0.430
replaced with another cap on <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR>, and not it shows = 0.399 and now I have a green light on the charger with my DC Supply but not normal charger.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is now 8.1v only

I will post some voltages now for you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
No Green light on the charger

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.1V
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_DATA</SIGNAL>  = 3.3
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_CLK</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_ENABLE</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDD</SIGNAL> = 1.2
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> = 0  (No corrosion around J6100)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Im going to change the SMC and we see what we get... 8.1v seems like an SMC issue... I'm also missing <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
So I changed the SMC and now have Greenlight/ orange light on the charger(8.5v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>).  As I suspected 8.1v it's an SMC failure.
I Will post new Voltages in a bit. Checking the board now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You should reballed it first.
Keep it in safe place and try it in a future repair.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thanks Master... Good Point.. I should have reballed it first and then used it again..  I did though do a reflow, and nothing happened that's why I changed it.. 

Working on the board now and will post some Voltages shortly within the next few hours.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Master [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER]

Please see following
[LIST=1]
[*]<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PPV_RTC_RST</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTC_RST</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_RSMT_RST</SIGNAL> = 3.3
[/LIST]

[B]Missing:[/B]
[LIST=1]
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>
[*]<SIGNAL>PP5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> for <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
[/LIST]

I changed the SMC again just for the sake of it, to the old one, reballed it as you said. Didn't work at all, no green light. So I have now changed back to another SMC and have green light again with these voltages above

feeling that PCH is broken and not outputting <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I don't see <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> listed there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 65941, member: 682"]
I don't see <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> listed there...
[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>  = 3.3v ON Pin 1 and output Pin 2 to PCh = 2.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
If present, all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals should pulse too; check that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>  = 3.3

[I]Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.   [/I]Its not possible, the board is on two sides..  How?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"Its not possible..." :eek:
Use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thanks [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] I learned something new there with <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16

I triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL>  3.3v - 0v - 3.3v.. Still nothing... What's next you suggest?

On the Y1905 clock chip I get 50 mhz.. is that correct value? Shouldn't it be 25Mhz.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: So <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> doesn't drop at same time with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Yes, it drops to 335.0mv

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Then check if any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signal pulses at same time.
